Posts.Content: Hi, I was given dihydracodeine, paracetamol & ibuprofen for pain, lactulose (to counteract effects of codeine) and cyclizine for sickness. Everyone's different when it comes to pain relief etc. so if your painkillers aren't working, get someone to ring your GP or BCN and ask for something different to what you have. I was constantly told that it's unnecessary to be in pain and it won't help your recovery.  Sending you warmest wishes xx
Posts.Title: Sickness and pain, advice needed.

Posts.Content: Hi Hawkster,    so sorry you find yourself here, but this is a great place to vent, ask questions, get advice and feel completely supported by those who have been where you currently are.    I was diagnosed last October aged 47, 2 kids aged 19 & 16 and a husband who has the patience of a saint. Having lost my mam very quickly to ovarian cancer I assumed I wouldn't be here to see the summer but here I am! I've had a mastectomy, some lymph nodes out, I'm part way through reconstruction with more surgery in Sept. and hysterectomy early next year. I found being open and honest with my kids has helped them to cope as they know I'm not keeping secrets, we all have good & bad days but I'm still here, back at work and off on hols this week so what I'm trying to say is you will find a way of coping in the best way you can, just do what feels right for you and your family. I felt calmer once I had my treatment plan and I hope that once you have yours you will feel the same.  Sending you & your family good wishes xx
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed and terrified.

Posts.Content: Hi Ruby Rock, seems unfair that you have to wait so long for results but I agree it will be protocol that the doctor ordering the biopsies will give you the results. I didn't ask any questions when I was having biopsies as I thought it might just be a routine thing to do. As for the 'oh bugger' comment it could have been an ill timed remark and she could have said it for an entirely different reason to what you're thinking, but I can understand why you are assuming the worst.  Stay busy, stay away from Google and focus only on what is known, everything else will only cause you anxiety. Sending you good wishes and positive thoughts xx

Posts.Title: Re. nipple tattoos, can you help?

Posts.Content: Hi, I had an abnormal CA125 result 18 months ago, this resulted in CT & MRI scans, thankfully all clear. However due to family history of ovarian/stomach/bowel and my breast cancer I was referred to genetics. Fast forward to now, BRCA1 & 2 negative but still considered high risk for ovarian cancer so although I'm just under the genetic threshold for genetic recommending ovaries & Fallopian tubes removed they referred me back to gynecologist who strongly recommend total hysterectomy for me. I've given this a lot of thought and as I'm in my 40's decided to go ahead with it.  I did ask for regular CA125's as an alternative to hysterectomy but was told that would be classed as screening and so they can't do this as NHS currently don't have a screening programme for ovarian cancer. CA125 is only an indicator not a reliable diagnostic tool. I was told CA125 could be raised due to pelvic infection/endometriosis etc. Not sure if that helps at all, feel free to ask anything x

Posts.Title: Newbie - confused and scared

Posts.Content: Hello ladies, I was told last week that I have a 27mm lump and lots of calcification around it. I have been told that I have to return to see the consultant this Thursday when he will discuss my treatment plan with me. I telephone the breast Nurse to ask for clarification and she advised me that my treatment will be an operation and chemo (not neccessarily in that order), and maybe other treatments depending on the biopsy results. She told me that the radiographer marked my report as lump (score 5) and calcification (4). I'm now scared stupid that this means it's stage 5/4. I'm worried about so many things at the moment mostly the unknown, I just want Thursday to be here so I know exactly what I'm dealing with and what lies ahead. I have told my immediate family the situation but no one beyond them. I think I'm hoping the doctor will say it's all been a massive mistake and there's nothing wrong with me...Roll on Thursday 4pm! Any advice on what to ask the doctor will be very helpful. Lola xx
Posts.Title: Newbie - confused and scared

Posts.Content: Hi again, I was automatically referred to O/H and had a phone consultation with their doctor. He understood the situation and surprisingly offered to suggest a further month off work as I was so run down and kept getting colds etc. on top of everything else.  I declined this but we agreed a phased return to work over 6 weeks, with a limit on not driving for more than 30mins per day for 2 weeks. This was really helpful as I'm also a community worker and drive a lot for work. I received a copy of the report, which was also very helpful. I also lost my confidence and I was very anxious when I did go back to work but at the same time I was desperate to get back and I felt ready, the phased return made a big difference.  Do you feel like you're counting down the days until your sick note runs out and stressing about asking for another? Perhaps you're just not ready to go back yet? xx

Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a left side Mx/SLNB/LD flap recon and had 5 months off work and I felt guilty about it. My job is physically and mentally demanding and I just wasn't ready to go back sooner. My employer was very supportive. However, when I had to go in to have the tissue expander exchanged for a permanent implant and revision to my back scar I was asked "how long will you be off work for this time?" and also had comments about it just being cosmetic stuff.  My surgeon told me that I should take whatever time is needed as recovery isn't just physical, psychologically we go through a lot. He told me if my employer needed any clarification they could ring him and he'd talk them through the impact of cancer treatment.  You are covered by the disability act and if you are providing doctors notes your employer should accept and support you through your treatment. Though I know from experience, once the cancer was removed with the first surgery and I found out I didn't need chemo (thank God) everyone moved on. Unfortunately I can't do that yet as I have at least two more surgery/procedures to go through. Take the letter from the clinic and take the pressure off yourself, think of what you need, not what will please your employer. Wishing you well xx
Posts.Title: Work issues

Posts.Content: Ah that sounds much more positive Julezan. Take the time you need, Crystaljuju is right staffing issues are not something you need to worry about, that's their concern. I felt the same pressure after the Mx, going to the GP every couple of weeks for another sick note. After my recent surgery I said I needed about 8weeks off and my GP gave me a note for 8weeks so I wasn't under pressure and could focus on recovering. I think being clear about what I wanted/needed helped my GP as well.  Speak up for yourself, tell them what you need. Always here to chat, let us know how you get on xx

Posts.Title: survivor

Posts.Content: Hi all, I was diagnosed in October 2014 and have gone through a mastectomy, lymph nodes, LD flap reconstruction, numerous expansions, implant exchange, genetic testing and will likely have my ovaries and tubes removed next year. I had my pre op this week for more breast surgery end of Dec and I was told if I had any questions regarding the surgery I should call my BCN. I commented that I understood the procedure but wondered why I've never been asked if I needed to talk through the emotional and psychological impact of it all to which the nurse said but that's what your BCN is there for...is that true? My BCN has never asked if I need or want to talk about any of it, I have only spoken to her if I have a specific question and then I get a specific rushed answer. I've only called 3 times in 14 months and have always felt like she has more important things to attend to. If emotional support is part of a BCN role why wasn't I told this at the start - I feel a bit let down as there have been times I could've done with someone away from my family and friends to talk to. I was lucky enough not to need chemo but I also haven't had the benefit of meeting or talking to other ladies. Have I misunderstood the role of a BCN and done myself out of support or is it assumed if you don't ask for support you don't need it?
Posts.Title: A bit let down

Posts.Content: H, thank you both very much for your replies and advice. I will ask to be referred for counselling after my next op. I can appreciate BCN's must have a heavy workload mine just hasn't been visible or supportive in my opinion. Grogg, I'm glad you have been supported and I appreciate the link. I hope you are both doing well and merry Christmas to you too. Thank you again.
Posts.Title: A bit let down

Posts.Content: Hi, just looking for your thoughts. I had a mastectomy, 4 lymph nodes removed and reconstruction using muscle from my back just over a year ago. straight after the op my arm on the affected side was very painful and my hand was a bit swollen, this went away within a week or so and up until recently I've just had pain in my back on and off. The problem I have is since my op to exchange the expander implant my breast increases then decreases in size and over the past 2 weeks I've had pain and tightness in the same arm and back near my shoulder blade that has gradually got worse to the point that my GP has put me on Naproxen, dihydracodeine, paracetamol and a sleeping tablet as it is so bad I can't get more than an hours sleep due to the pain and discomfort. Yesterday my hand was very slightly swollen but has gone overnight, however, my back feels a bit odd near my shoulder blade. My GP thinks it's a frozen shoulder but I have full movement of it so I'm not sure about that. The tablets aren't relieving it at all, the only thing that helps is putting pressure on my arm by lying on it when I'm in bed. I think this is something to do with the op I had even though it was some time ago and I just wondered if anyone has experienced anything similar or can offer any advice As to what may be the problem (I haven't done anything different or lifted anything heavy to cause a strain). Any thoughts are welcome xx
Posts.Title: Intense Pain in Back, Arm & Hand

Posts.Content: Thank you both for the advice. I hadn't really considered lymphoedema as I thought that would cause my whole arm to be noticeably swollen, which it isn't. I will give a call on Monday and ask for it to be checked xx
Posts.Title: Intense Pain in Back, Arm & Hand

Posts.Content: Hi Hawkster, it's perfectly normal to feel this way and have the worries you do. I agree with Crystaljuju share your feelings with at least one person, more if you can. I was like you, brave face, keeping strong for everyone else but had a couple of meltdowns at home. I ended up resenting people telling me how well I was coping etc. but then I realised this was the impression I gave them. I had a 6 week wait for surgery from diagnosis, not long but felt like forever. Try to keep busy and use the time to get everything ready for when you come home. I had my skin sparing Mx SLNB & LD flap reconstruction last Dec and at times still can't believe I turned up for it as but I'm glad I did, the cancer is gone and whilst not the breast I started out with I have an excellent result from the recon. I don't know if you're having reconstruction too? The surgeon showed me pics of his work and I couldn't get over how good they looked. Make use of your BCN as well, they are there to support you too. Keep posting as everyone here will support you through this and feel free to add me as a friend xx
